# The Auditor's Responsibility in the Audit of Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatements due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with Audit Commission auditing standards will necessarily detect any material misstatements that may exist. Misstatements may arise from fraud or error, and they are considered material if, individually or in aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit process conducted in accordance with the Audit Commission's audit standards, I apply professional judgment and maintain a professional skeptical attitude. I also:
- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements arising from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Since fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, false statements, or overriding of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements due to fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those due to error;
- Understand internal controls relevant to the audit in order to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group's internal controls;
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Monetary Authority are appropriate, and whether its accounting estimates and related disclosures are reasonable;
- Determine whether the Monetary Authority's use of the going concern basis of accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are material uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I believe that such material uncertainties exist, it is necessary to draw the users' attention to the related disclosures in the financial statements in the auditor's report. If the related disclosures are insufficient, I must issue a non-unqualified auditor's report. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may cause the Group to be unable to continue as a going concern;
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly reflect the transactions and events; and
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group in order to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the Group audit. I take full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Sub-Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the audit, as well as significant audit findings, including any material weaknesses in internal control identified during the audit period.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Sub-Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, confirming that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicating to them all relationships and other matters that may reasonably be considered to affect my independence, as well as the relevant safeguards where applicable.

# 2.3 Subsidiaries and Non-Controlling Interests

Subsidiaries refer to entities controlled by the Group. The Group is deemed to have control over an entity if it is exposed to risks or has rights related to variable returns from its involvement in the entity's operations, and has the ability to exercise power over the entity to affect those returns. When assessing whether the Group has power, only the substantive rights held by the Group and other parties are considered.
